title: Episode 22: Deconstruction and Reconstruction
description: Today I talk through the definitions of deconstruction, what I believe people are trying to communicate through the word and how we can use deconstruction to get us to a place of reconstruction. I hope you enjoy! Please feel free to leave your thoughts below.

transcript_parts.text: [Music]

things more responsibly

in the last couple weeks i've been

start talking about the the definitions

there are people who understand know

have never heard the term they don't

weeks as i was trying to kind of figure

how's a good way to describe

just from dictionary.com
but deconstruction a method of critical

language which emphasizes the internal
workings of language and conceptual
systems
the relation quality of meaning and the
assumption implicit
in forms of expression deconstruction
focuses on a text as such
rather than an expression of the

stressing the limitations or
impossibility of interpretation
and rejecting the western philosophical
tradition of seeking certainty through
reasoning
by privileging certain types of
interpretations and repressing others
it was effectively named and popularized
by the french philosopher
jacques derida from the late 1960s and
taken out particularly by the u.s
literary critics
now when i read that there's some pieces
of that that seem to
kind of correlate with this religious
deconstruction and the space
that a lot of uh
ex-christians or struggling christians
find themselves in but
it didn't quite hit the tone of of what

so from there i found another website
that gave five different
definitions of deconstruction sort of
the five top and i'll read those for you
deconstruction is defined as a way of
analyzing literature that assumes the

an example of deconstruction is reading

20 years apart and seeing how it has a
different meaning each time
the second a philosophical movement and
theory of literary criticism that
questions traditional assumptions about
certainty
identity and truth asserts that words
can only refer to other words
and attempts to demonstrate how

three an analytic method especially of

originated in france in the mid 20th

and usage no text can have a fixed
coherent meaning
for the destroying or taking a part of
an object

now again all of these definitions sort
of
i feel like have some sort of like touch
to
what people are really trying to get out
from deconstruction but it doesn't

to the core of what i think people are

really hit the nail on the head of what

at least in that religious or christian

now in short faith deconstruction is the
systematic pulling apart of one's belief
system
for examination for christians that can
mean a wide array
of questioning ranging from theological
to the practical
it can mean questioning the supposed
inerrancy of the bible the culture and

the particular application or

more
faith deconstruction can begin at many

for many different reasons doubt is what

the question underneath all the other

can i trust my beliefs and the way i

so in that frame it's very different
than
sort of not being able to trust the

or something within that although i

the packaged faith that many people were

the things that someone always knew and

and i know for myself and for many

that's a process that came
in a way that wasn't even expected or it

that was being sought after but
naturally came through the experience of

and just sort of this interaction with

inside and outside of our own

this pulling apart of faith is

and on one hand that's very

a somewhat negative outlook and

on one end we have people so fearful of

lack of intentionality of of the things

we're questioning and how to
really participate in that well
and both of these sort of extremes

now as a religious person myself i tend
to not be

to have flaws and examine that
